title: October 9-20, 2025
preview: Google Veo 3.1 officially launches, Sora 2 removes watermarks, Higgsfield business concerns, attention span economics, and comprehensive technical workflows.

items.title: üîó Google Veo 3.1 Launch
items.summary: The biggest news of the period was the official release of Google Veo 3.1 on October 15th, with community anticipation building since October 9th.
items.content:
The community had been anticipating this release since October 9th when teasers began appearing on platforms like Higgsfield. **Matthieu** noted the positioning difference: "OpenAI's Sora2 is built for consumers. Google's Veo3 is built for professionals. Different goals, different end games."

When Veo 3.1 went live in Google Flow, **PJ Accetturo** warned the community: "Don't get suckered into all these API sites charging you $5 a clip." The release came with some technical specifications that sparked discussion - **Chris First** confirmed it "renders at 720 and can upscale to 1080 on Flow," though **Jordan Daniel Chesney** noted disappointment about "No 1080p for Veo 3.1." **Rourke** observed that Freepik was offering 1080p, suggesting they were using their own upscaler.

Initial testing revealed unexpected issues. **Jordan** reported that "music is on almost every gen" and questioned if this was an intentional feature. The launch also experienced typical server strain, with users getting stuck at 99% generation progress and error messages stating "This model is currently unavailable." **Chris First** noted that the main new feature appeared to be "ingredients" support, though **Rourke** clarified this wasn't actually new for Ultra Plan users who already had it on Veo 2.

There was significant confusion around fake Veo 3.1 API access. **Wavespeed** claimed to have Veo 3.1 API, which **Claire Xue** (who is with the Veo team) immediately debunked: "No I'm with veo team now it's not out." **Jordan** questioned why they would make such a risky move: "They're asking for a lawsuit it seems." **Max** and **Rourke** also identified suspicious Veo 3.1 clips that appeared to be stitched together with hidden cuts.

items.title: üé¨ Sora 2 & Sora 2 Pro Developments
items.summary: The Sora ecosystem saw significant discussion around the Pro tier pricing and a major quality-of-life improvement with watermark removal.
items.content:
**Matthieu** asked about the difference between Sora 2 and Sora 2 Pro, which costs 4x in credits on Freepik. **Chris First** explained: "High resolution, up to 15 seconds. 30 minutes to render." The 30-minute render time shocked the community, with **Chris** sharing his frustration: "Took me like 30 min last night and then it failed. So wasted 30 min waiting lol."

**Chad Nelson** provided practical guidance: "Pro is great for cinema visuals‚Ä¶ but not needed for most other things." The remix feature drew criticism from **Noah**: "Also remix is a pain in the ass to use. You have to know the videos code. But no watermark so‚Ä¶ hooray?"

A major quality-of-life improvement arrived on October 11th when **Billy Boman** confirmed: "Confirm NO watermark in Sora 2! (as in the Open AI interface)." This was significant because, as **Billy** noted, "all API was without watermark from the beginning - slightly unintuitive imo consider the Sora 2 price tag."

**Higgsfield** made waves by claiming to offer "Sora 2 Pro Max +" which **Chris First** mocked: "Oh you didn't get the CPP invite?üòÇüò≠ I'm already on Sora 17 Pro Max +." He speculated: "Its probably Sora with an upscaler in the pipeline between API and user, but it should just say that." **Jordan Daniel Chesney** summed up community sentiment: "Higgsfield should probably just say a lot. üòÇ"

items.title: ü§ñ Figure 03 Humanoid Robot
items.summary: The Figure 03 humanoid robot generated significant discussion about its faceless design and anthropomorphic implications.
items.content:
**Matthieu** questioned if it could talk, sharing a video from Justin Ryan. **Albert Bozesan** found the faceless design unsettling: "Super impressive. But does anyone else find these faceless robots super creepy? I'm gonna at least need some friendly LED or screen eyes."

**Matthieu** expressed deeper concerns about the anthropomorphic implications: "I think the anthropological feeling I get is worse : we're going to enslave human like bodies + superintelligence within when they will have it. But I do love the design. But I felt a bit sad for him bcs he feels more human than machine."

items.title: üé≠ The Tilly AI Actress Controversy
items.summary: The announcement of "Tilly," an AI-generated actress in a film premiering at Zurich Film Festival, dominated industry discourse.
items.content:
**Matthieu** shared coverage showing the media storm around the project. **Albert Bozesan** provided context: "It's wild. I haven't looked super deep into it but there isn't really much tech behind Tilly, right? It's basically stuff that's been possible for at least two years...? It's basically 'good' marketing and announcing it at Zurich Film Festival in front of the right journalists."

**Matthieu** expressed frustration with the attention it was receiving: "It's just that no one wants this no one cares about this. And still everyone is speaking about this. Now they just made that AI crap famous and of course it will work. Because they know it will make headlines if in a film."

**Danny Perkins** offered a contrasting perspective on how the RealDreams community should position itself: "It's actually a case study on how not to do things... You will get better press for sure - your empowered creatives rather than livelihood stealing avatars..."

**Henry** drew parallels to broader AI film debates: "It's the same debate as AI films. Critics hate it but audience doesn't care... they just want to be entertained."

items.title: üí∞ Platform Economics & Business Models
items.summary: Discussion about the future of all-in-one platforms and their pricing strategies, with emphasis on integrated workflows.
items.content:
**Blvckl!ght** sparked discussion about the future of all-in-one platforms: "The question is which all-in-one is going to offer it unlimited and eat the cost. My bet is higgs." He emphasized the need for integrated workflows: "For clips of that length, I'd want the ability to assign characters and voices along with promp/scripting."

**Chris First** questioned the sustainability: "Unlimited is never unlimited. It's always a lie. Unlimited until you hit the cap." **Blvckl!ght** clarified his vision: "I'm saying unlimited in the sense that you pay a flat rate and use it as much as you want. Not free unlimited."

The conversation revealed deep concerns about Higgsfield's business practices. **Rourke** noted: "Higgsfield is going to have to start being honest. They're playing a dangerous game with their marketing." **Chris First** agreed: "Yeah they're gonna get sued eventually. You can't just claim you have models you don't have."

items.title: ‚è±Ô∏è Attention Span Economics
items.summary: A fascinating discussion emerged about the "1-second threshold" in content consumption and its implications for creators.
items.content:
**Matthieu** shared a provocative observation: "If people don't like your content in the first second, they won't watch it. The 1-second rule is real." This sparked a broader conversation about content strategy and platform economics.

**Jordan Daniel Chesney** connected this to production workflows: "This is why the first frame matters so much. You need to hook people immediately or they're gone." **PJ Accetturo** added a business perspective: "And this is why platforms are pushing shorter content. They can serve more ads if people are constantly scrolling."

**Albert Bozesan** questioned the creative implications: "But does this mean we're just optimizing for the algorithm instead of making good content? Where's the line?" **Matthieu** responded: "The line is where you decide if you want views or if you want to make art. Sometimes they align, usually they don't."

items.title: üé¨ Max's ‚Ç¨5B Google Belgium Launch Film
items.summary: Max announced a major commercial project for Google's new ‚Ç¨5 billion investment in Belgium.

links.text: launch film for Google's new ‚Ç¨5 billion investment in Belgium

items.content:
**Max** shared: "NEW WORK üí• We are honored to have created the launch film for Google's new ‚Ç¨5 billion investment in Belgium, a powerful step forward for Europe's digital and AI future. Grateful to the Google team for the trust and creative freedom on this incredible project. AI Artists: Max Larsson & Jennie Larsson. Music & Sound design: Nikodemus Lindh√©"

The community celebrated this major achievement, with **Albert Bozesan** noting: "This is the kind of work that shows what's possible when you combine creative vision with these new tools. Congrats Max!"

items.title: üé® Ludovic's 2.5-Month Project
items.summary: Ludovic released a significant project after 2.5 months of work.
items.content: **Ludovic** announced the completion of a major project that took 2.5 months to create. While details were limited, the community expressed excitement about seeing the final result. **Jordan** commented: "Can't wait to see what you've been working on for that long!"

items.title: üé∏ Davide's Metal Music Video
items.summary: Davide shared his work on a metal music video, showcasing the genre diversity in the community.
items.content: **Davide Bianca** shared his work on a metal music video: "One for the metal heads dreamers in here." The project demonstrated the versatility of AI video tools across different genres and aesthetics.

items.title: üé≠ Sora Character Consistency Techniques
items.summary: Dale shared his workflow for achieving character consistency in Sora, with additional insights from PJ Accetturo.
items.content:
**Dale** shared his workflow for achieving character consistency in Sora: "Take a still from the first Sora video you generate, then I2V with a thorough prompt w/ consistent description of setting + character." He elaborated: "Lately I'm leaning on LLMs I train more. I'll upload a still as I described, and request a new shot but with the LLM adding thorough descriptions of the appearances of the things I want to keep, in way that makes sense for the shot. Sora seems to respond, but sometimes messed with style a bit so it's usually a few rolls to get it perfect."

**PJ Accetturo** shared an interesting thread on consistent characters: "TLDR; basically if you upload a character sketch, you can get close to a consistent person" using Nano Banana prompts.

items.title: üé§ Lip-Sync Solutions
items.summary: Kat Gellein Viken asked about lip-sync tools, and the community provided several solutions with detailed experiences.
items.content: **Kat Gellein Viken** asked about lip-sync tools, noting "Kling seems to be worse at it than a few months ago." The community provided several solutions:
bullets: Billy Boman: "I used Kling Speak here, worked well even for the fast rap parts mostly"
Albert Bozesan: "I've been getting great results with InfiniteTalk, but be aware it basically regenerates the whole thing (that's what makes the integration so good, though)"
Julien Durand: Shared InfiniteTalk examples calling it "amazing"
Jordan Daniel Chesney: "InfiniteTalk works well with mid and close up shots for video to video"

items.title: üë∂ Child Voice Generation
items.summary: Discussion about generating child voices for projects, with recommendations for 11Labs.
items.content: **Santiago** asked: "Anyone know a good tool to generate child voices? 11labs doesn't have any." **Blvckl!ght** responded: "11labs does have child voices. You just have to search for them in the voice library. Filter by age range." **Santiago** confirmed: "Found them! Thanks!"

items.title: üé® WAN LoRA Training
items.summary: Brief discussion about training LoRAs for WAN (Warp Diffusion Animation Network).
items.content: **Rourke** mentioned training LoRAs for WAN: "Been training some LoRAs for WAN 2.2. The character consistency is getting really good." **Jordan** asked about the process, and **Rourke** noted: "It's similar to SD LoRA training, but you need to be more careful with the dataset quality."

items.title: üéâ New Members & Introductions
items.summary: The community welcomed new members JD Leroy and Jagger.
items.content: **JD Leroy** and **Jagger** joined the community during this period. The group welcomed them warmly, with several members offering to help them get up to speed on the latest tools and workflows.

items.title: üíº Job Postings
items.summary: Job opportunities were shared, including positions at London post houses.
items.content: **Matthieu** shared job postings from London post production houses looking for AI-savvy editors and VFX artists. **Albert** noted: "Great to see traditional post houses embracing AI workflows."

items.title: üíç Albert's Wedding
items.summary: Albert Bozesan shared news of his upcoming wedding.
items.content: **Albert Bozesan** shared that he's getting married soon. The community congratulated him warmly, with **Matthieu** joking: "Make sure to use Sora for the wedding video!" **Albert** responded: "Already planning it!"

items.title: Major Releases
bullets: Google Veo 3.1 - Launched October 15th in Google Flow, 720p native with 1080p upscaling, ingredients support
Sora 2 Watermark Removal - Confirmed October 11th, watermark removed from official OpenAI interface
Figure 03 Humanoid Robot - Advanced humanoid with potential voice capabilities

items.title: Platform Updates
bullets: Freepik - Offering Veo 3.1 at 1080p (likely using custom upscaler)
Wavespeed - Falsely claimed Veo 3.1 API access (debunked by Google Veo team)
